text: The stone which the builders refused is become the head stone of the corner.
text_kjv: The stone which the builders refused is become the head stone of the corner.
text_niv: The stone the builders rejectedhas become the capstone;
text_esv: The stone that the builders rejected has become the cornerstone.
text_nlt: The stone that the builders rejectedhas now become the cornerstone.
text_msg: The stone the masons discarded as flawedis now the capstone!
text_nasb: The stone which the builders rejected Has become the chief corner [stone].
context: Psalm 118 is a hymn of thanksgiving, likely sung during a festival procession, perhaps the Feast of Tabernacles or Passover. It celebrates God's steadfast love (Hebrew: *chesed*) and His deliverance of the Psalmist (representing Israel) from enemies. The Psalm begins with a call to give thanks to the Lord and recounts past struggles and victories. The repetition of "His mercy endures forever" emphasizes the unwavering nature of God's covenant with His people. Historically, Psalm 118 could relate to specific events in Israel's history, such as a military victory or the rebuilding of the temple. The phrase "The stone which the builders refused" resonates strongly with the rebuilding of the Second Temple after the Babylonian exile. During this period, resources and manpower were scarce, and the selection of building materials was crucial. Rejection of a particular stone might have occurred due to perceived flaws, unsuitable size, or simply aesthetic preferences. The cornerstone, the foundation stone laid at the corner of a building, was of utmost importance for structural integrity. Its selection and placement were carefully planned. The phrase "head of the corner" can also refer to a capstone, the crowning stone completing an arch or structure, signifying completion and stability. The verse's placement within Psalm 118 suggests it's not merely about physical construction but also about a larger, more profound reality of God's providential work. The image evokes the surprise and triumph of God's choice, elevating the rejected element to a position of prominence and significance.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 118:22 foreshadows the rejection and subsequent exaltation of Jesus Christ. The "stone which the builders refused" directly parallels Jesus, who was rejected by the religious leaders of His time – the very individuals who saw themselves as the builders and guardians of God's house, Israel. These leaders, blind to His true identity as the Messiah, dismissed Him as insignificant, an obstacle to their established power structures and theological interpretations. They failed to recognize His divine authority and His role in fulfilling the prophecies of the Old Testament. However, despite their rejection, God raised Jesus from the dead and made Him the cornerstone of a new spiritual temple – the Church. This resurrection and ascension to God's right hand signified His ultimate triumph over death and sin, making Him the foundation and capstone of salvation. The "head of the corner" represents Jesus' supreme authority and His role as the unifying element holding together the entire structure of the Christian faith. He is both the foundation upon which salvation is built and the completion of God's redemptive plan. This verse highlights the paradoxical nature of God's ways, often choosing the weak, the despised, and the rejected to accomplish His purposes. It underscores the importance of humility and recognizing God's hand at work even in unexpected places. The rejected stone becoming the cornerstone symbolizes the victory of God's plan over human resistance and the ultimate vindication of Jesus Christ.
application: In our modern lives, Psalm 118:22 offers several powerful applications. Firstly, it encourages us to recognize and value the overlooked and marginalized members of our society. Like the rejected stone, individuals who are deemed insignificant or unimportant by the world may possess unique gifts and potential that God can use in profound ways. We should actively seek out and support those who are rejected or marginalized, offering them opportunities to contribute and shine. Secondly, it speaks to the importance of perseverance in the face of rejection. Just as Jesus endured rejection and ultimately triumphed, we too can overcome obstacles and achieve our God-given purpose, even when facing opposition or discouragement. Rejection can be a catalyst for growth and refinement, shaping us into stronger and more resilient individuals. Thirdly, the verse challenges us to re-evaluate our own biases and prejudices. We must be willing to challenge our own assumptions and preconceived notions about people and situations, allowing God to open our eyes to possibilities we might have previously overlooked. Are we, in our own ways, rejecting valuable stones that God intends to use? Fourthly, it reminds us to find our foundation and completion in Christ. In a world that constantly shifts and changes, Jesus remains the steadfast cornerstone, providing stability and purpose. We must build our lives upon His teachings and strive to live in accordance with His will. Fifthly, this verse calls us to embrace the unconventional and unexpected. God often works in mysterious ways, using seemingly insignificant events and individuals to accomplish His grand design. We must be open to His leading, even when it doesn't align with our own plans or expectations. Finally, this verse is encouragement for those who feel rejected or overlooked. God sees your potential, even if others don't. He can take what others dismiss and use it for His glory, making you a cornerstone in His kingdom.
prayer: Lord Jesus, thank you for being the rejected stone who became the cornerstone. Forgive me for the times I have overlooked or dismissed those You value. Open my eyes to see the potential in those who are marginalized and rejected by the world. Help me to embrace the unconventional and trust in Your sovereign plan, even when I don't understand it. Give me the strength to persevere in the face of rejection, knowing that You are with me. Lord, help me to build my life upon You, the solid and unshakeable foundation. May I find my purpose and fulfillment in Your love and grace. Fill me with compassion for those who are hurting and rejected, and empower me to be a source of encouragement and hope in their lives. I offer you my life, my gifts, and my talents, asking that you use them for Your glory. Amen.

faqs.answer: Psalm 118:22 is directly quoted in the New Testament (Matthew 21:42, Mark 12:10, Luke 20:17, Acts 4:11, 1 Peter 2:7) referring to Jesus as the Messiah who was rejected by the Jewish leaders but exalted by God to become the cornerstone of the Church. The Gospels make clear connections.
faqs.question: Q1: How does Psalm 118:22 relate to Jesus' ministry?

faqs.answer: The phrase 'head of the corner' can refer either to the cornerstone, the foundational block, or the capstone, the finishing stone. In either case, it signifies a position of vital importance, strength, stability, and completion. The rejected stone now is the most vital piece.
faqs.question: Q2: What does it mean that the stone became the 'head of the corner'?

faqs.answer: Recognize that God can bring good out of difficult situations and turn rejection into opportunities for growth. Trust that even when others dismiss you, God sees your potential and can use you for His purposes. Persevere, and let your faith guide you.
faqs.question: Q3: How can I apply this verse to my own life's challenges?

faqs.answer: While primarily interpreted as a prophecy of Jesus, the verse also speaks to a broader principle of God elevating the humble and rejected. It highlights the importance of recognizing value in unexpected places and trusting in God's unexpected plans. It speaks of redemption in every area of our lives.
faqs.question: Q4: Is this verse only about Jesus, or does it have other applications?

faqs.answer: It compels us to see potential and value in all people, especially those who are marginalized or rejected by society. It reminds us that God often works through the unexpected, raising up the humble to positions of influence and importance. See everyone through eyes of love.
